docs.snippet: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1984 More than 100 more Polish tourists on a cruise to West Germany have abandoned a ferryboat with the apparent intention of seeking political asylum, the West German border police said. The episode brings to 428 the number of...
docs.lead_paragraph: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1984 More than 100 more Polish tourists on a cruise to West Germany have abandoned a ferryboat with the apparent intention of seeking political asylum, the West German border police said. The episode brings to 428 the number of Polish travelers who have jumped ship in West German ports in the last two weeks seeking to emigrate to the the West. (Page 1, Column 3.) U.S. and North Korean officers blamed each other for the exchange of gunfire at the Panmunjom truce area between North and South Korea Friday that left four soldiers dead and as many as six wounded. (3:3.)

docs.snippet: UNDER flawed conditions, Uruguay is holding elections today for a president and congress. If everything goes according to schedule, civilians will assume power in March after more than 11 years of military rule.
docs.lead_paragraph: UNDER flawed conditions, Uruguay is holding elections today for a president and congress. If everything goes according to schedule, civilians will assume power in March after more than 11 years of military rule.

headline.main: DEMOCRACY GAINS IN CENTRAL AND SOUTH AMERICA

docs.snippet: Uruguayans are scheduled to vote Sunday for a civilian Government to end 11 years of repressive military rule.    On the eve of the election, the first since 1971, many Uruguayans seemed more relieved at the dictatorship's imminent demise than...
docs.lead_paragraph: Uruguayans are scheduled to vote Sunday for a civilian Government to end 11 years of repressive military rule. On the eve of the election, the first since 1971, many Uruguayans seemed more relieved at the dictatorship's imminent demise than concerned over which of the three main presidential candidates would win. Huge rallies marked the end of campaigning at midnight Friday. Excited followers of different parties crowded the streets of Montevideo today waving colored flags, distributing pamphlets and blowing car horns in support of their candidates.

headline.main: URUGUAY TO PICK CIVILIAN LEADER IN ELECTION TODAY, FIRST SINCE '71

docs.snippet: Uruguay held general elections today for the first time in 13 years, recovering a democratic tradition that had long distinguished the country within Latin America.     If Gen. Gregorio Alvarez surrenders power as planned on March 1, Uruguay will...
docs.lead_paragraph: Uruguay held general elections today for the first time in 13 years, recovering a democratic tradition that had long distinguished the country within Latin America. If Gen. Gregorio Alvarez surrenders power as planned on March 1, Uruguay will become the eighth nation in the region to switch from military to civilian rule since 1980. Early returns from Montevideo gave a firm lead to the center-right Colorado Party and its presidential candidate, Julio Maria Sanguinetti, a 48- year-old lawyer and journalist, who was also doing better than expected in the interior. The voting took place today in a mood of great enthusiasm, with the colors of the three main parties visible everywhere in the capital. About 630,000 of the 2.2 million eligible voters were going to the polls for the first time, and a large turnout was reported.

byline.original: By ALAN RIDING, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: In the last 11 years, while thousands of Uruguyans were jailed and tens of thousands more were forced into exile, Julio Maria Sanguinetti avoided a confrontation with the military regime, convinced that it could be coaxed - but never forced - out of...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the last 11 years, while thousands of Uruguyans were jailed and tens of thousands more were forced into exile, Julio Maria Sanguinetti avoided a confrontation with the military regime, convinced that it could be coaxed - but never forced - out of office. Mr. Sanguinetti's election Sunday in Uruguay's first presidential elections since 1971 provided vindication of this strategy: two outspoken political leaders were banned as candidates, but the dictatorship should end on March 1. ''Julio is a born negotiator,'' an old friend said today. ''He's very rational, he's a cold decision-maker. You won't see him acting emotionally.''

docs.snippet: A centrist politician who played a key role in persuading Uruguay's military regime to leave office has been elected to head the country's first civilian Government in 11 years.   As his victory became apparent early today, Julio Maria Sanguinetti, a...
docs.lead_paragraph: A centrist politician who played a key role in persuading Uruguay's military regime to leave office has been elected to head the country's first civilian Government in 11 years. As his victory became apparent early today, Julio Maria Sanguinetti, a 48-year-old lawyer who was nominated by the Colorado Party, called on the defeated candidates and parties in the election Sunday to help him form ''a Government of national understanding.'' He promised to seek the broadest possible consensus ''so that this Government can consolidate Uruguayan democracy and forever bury the past.'' Embraced by Opponent In an important symbolic gesture, his main challenger, Alberto Saenz de Zumaran of the National or Blanco Party, traveled to the Colorado Party headquarters before dawn to embrace Mr. Sanguinetti in front of a cheering crowd that began singing the national anthem.

docs.snippet: ''Uruguay knew poverty, but it never before knew misery. Now we face a problem of generalized misery.
docs.lead_paragraph: ''Uruguay knew poverty, but it never before knew misery. Now we face a problem of generalized misery.

docs.snippet: In the late 1970's, 13 of Latin America's 20 republics were governed by generals, Haiti was ruled by a family dynasty and a Communist dictator was in power in Cuba. Democracy, long preferred by inhabitants of the region, seemed headed for extinction....
docs.lead_paragraph: In the late 1970's, 13 of Latin America's 20 republics were governed by generals, Haiti was ruled by a family dynasty and a Communist dictator was in power in Cuba. Democracy, long preferred by inhabitants of the region, seemed headed for extinction. Then suddenly the trend changed. On Sunday Uruguay became the eighth Latin American country to elect a civilian President since 1980 and Brazil and Guatemala should follow suit next year. Today only Chile, Paraguay and Haiti are still firmly in the grip of rightist dictators. The Reagan Administration has claimed partial credit for this turnaround. Excluding events preceding the United States invasion of Grenada, no civilian Government was ousted in the region during the President's first term, while Vice President Bush attended the inaugurations of a succession of newly elected governments.
